page.title: 16ANGLING AT BEDGEBURY LAKE
page.content: The Great Lake has long been an established coarse fishing and is controlled for angling by the Cranbrook & District Angling Club. The lake holds good quality tench, roach, rudd, perch and pike, and recently bream have grown in number. The main method of angling is by float or ledger tackle, with bread, sweetcorn, maggot and worm being the most common baits used. The lake's large variations in depth allow the angler a wide variety of swims to fish, from the deepest by the dam wall where depths of 14 feet can be found to areas at the inlet end with only 2 or 3 feet of water and large patches of water lilies. This water with its attractive setting and abundance of wildlife is an ideal place for the serious and casual angler alike.
